newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan Sugar says buys 3-yr, 180,000T sugar supply.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan Sugar says buys 3-yr, 180,000T sugar supply.

text.p: State-owned Taiwan Sugar Corp said on Monday it had completed a contract to buy 60,000 tonnes of sugar a year over three years from January 1997 from Czarnikow, setting the deal at a private tender in New York.
"We have decided to buy the three-year sugar supply from Czarnikow," a Taiwan Sugar executive confirmed to Reuters by telephone.
The executive said the deal was reached on Thursday in New York at an invitation-only tender but not disclosed publicly and that pricing details would remain confidential.
"Both sides have agreed not to disclose the purchase price in a long-term relationship," he added.
Shipments and freight would be set with Czarnikow, a British specialist supplier, as actual demand occurs, the Taiwan Sugar executive said.
Taiwan's state sugar monopoly is on track to import 120,000 tonnes of sugar in 1996, industry sources have said.
Taiwan Sugar bought two 30,000-tonne shipments of sugar on June 26 in New York at US$305.50 and US$302 per tonne on a cost-and-freight basis.
Traders said the company hoped to streamline its sugar procurement by landing one long-term contract rather than relying on smaller as-needed tenders.
Taiwan Sugar, like most state companies on the rapidly liberalising island, is under mandate to privatise.
But the cabinet, in a June 27 ruling, determined it would not face serious competition before 2002.
